source.raw_text:
The Sandbag Strict Press is a compound exercise building total-body strength, heavily targeting the deltoids, triceps, and upper back for the press itself, while engaging the core (abs, obliques, lower back) and legs (glutes, hamstrings) for stabilization, creating a dynamic, functional movement that enhances shoulder stability, grip, and coordination due to the shifting sand load. Key movement patterns include shoulder flexion, scapular stabilization, and intense core bracing to manage the uneven weight. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked: 

• Primary Movers (Upper Body): 

    • Deltoids (Shoulders): All three heads (anterior, lateral, posterior) work to lift the weight overhead, especially the front delts. 
    • Triceps: Extend the elbow to lock out the press. 
    • Upper Back (Traps, Rhomboids, Serratus Anterior): Stabilize the shoulder blades and maintain posture. 

• Stabilizers (Whole Body): 

    • Core (Abs, Obliques, Lower Back): Constantly brace and adjust to the shifting sand for spinal stability. 
    • Glutes & Hamstrings: Provide a solid base and help generate force, crucial for overall stability. 
    • Forearms & Grip: Work hard to maintain control of the unstable sandbag. [1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]  

Movement Patterns: 

• Shoulder Flexion: The primary action of raising the arm overhead. 
• Scapular Stabilization: Retracting and controlling the shoulder blades to create a stable platform. 
• Core Bracing & Anti-Rotation: The uneven load forces intense core engagement to prevent leaning or twisting. 
• Hip Hinging (Setup): Often involves a slight hip hinge to get the bag into the rack position. 
• Full-Body Integration: The sandbag demands total body tension, linking the lower body, core, and upper body for a synergistic effort. [1, 2, 5, 9, 10, 11]  

Key Sandbag Element: 

• Dynamic Load: The shifting sand requires constant micro-adjustments, challenging stabilizer muscles more than a rigid barbell, improving functional strength and coordination. [2, 5, 9]
